Introduction

In the context of this policy the Equality Act (2010) places a legal duty on all service providers to make reasonable adjustments for service users and/or parents and carers of patients who have information and/or communication support needs relating to a disability, impairment or sensory loss.

This policy ensures that measures are in place to support people who have been identified as needing information in alternative or specific formats; use of specific or alternative contact methods; or arranging support from a communication professional.

This policy sets out the clear and stringent standards required to meet the communication/support needs of those individuals' who are disabled; blind; d/Deaf; deafblind; have a learning disability; aphasia, autism or mental health condition. These standards are in place to ensure that the Trust provides a good equitable service and minimises the risks stemming from poor communication.

In this context, the term d/Deaf is used and refers to people who are Deaf – using sign language only and people who are deaf - hard of hearing but who have English as their first language and may lip-read and/or use hearing aids.

It sets out what patients, their carers and staff can expect when using MSEFT services with regards to identifying, flagging, sharing and meeting individuals' information and/or communication support needs, which is in line with legislation relating to the accessible information standards launched in 2016.
Purpose

The ability to communicate between healthcare staff, patients and their relatives or carers is fundamental to clinical care. The purpose of this policy is to describe the specific, consistent, essential practices and processes required for the implementation of providing accessible information.

It is provided for those service users and visitors who need it and have information and/or communication support needs relating to a disability, impairment or sensory loss; in order to avoid putting a disabled person at a substantial disadvantage when compared to a person who is not disabled.

It will raise awareness, direct, inform and ensure that Mid and South Essex Foundation Trust (MSEFT) staff, volunteers, and other people representing MSEFT plan proactively for the service user's, relatives, carers and visitors information and communication support needs where it is required.

It will ensure that staff, volunteers, and other people representing MSEFT are provided with the appropriate knowledge and skills to take all actions required to ensure that service users and visitor's diverse information and communication support needs are met.

There is a legal requirement for staff, volunteers, and other people representing MSEFT to provide a reasonably adjusted service and this policy is to ensure that everything possible is done to deliver an equitable service with regards to communication and information.

In implementing the policy, staff, volunteers, and other people representing MSEFT will be aware of their responsibility to complete five distinct steps leading to the achievement of five clear outcomes.

This policy ensures that adults, children and young people with information and / or communication support needs are provided with appropriate – including age-appropriate – information and communication support where it is required.
Aims and Objectives

The overall aim of this policy is to establish a framework and set clear direction to overcome any existing barriers in order to enable people who have a disability, impairment or sensory loss, to have access to information on their health and care needs in a format that they can easily read and understand.

MSEFT is committed to putting patients and carers first to improve their health and wellbeing. The Trust aims to uphold their legal and moral obligation to make sure that people can understand the information they are given about their health and social care.

The Trust also wants everyone to be enabled to be involved in making decisions about their health, care and treatment and make informed choices, taking some control about the issues that affect them in a timely and sensitive manner.

A further aim is to outline the accessible information services available to staff, patients, carers, relatives and the public to ensure that no individual or minority group is excluded from services/information for any reason:
Accessible information – information which is able to be read or received and understood by the intended individual and
Communication support – support which is needed to enable effective, accurate dialogue between a professional and a service user to take place.

This includes, audio, either BSL face-to-face or telephone based Interpreters, and those who require written information available in easy-read, large print, deafblind manual, Block communication, Visual Frame and hands on BSL for example.

This policy is built on the social model of disability and staff at MSEFT have a legal duty under the Accessible Information Standards (2016) and the Equality Act (2010) to make reasonable adjustments which aims to remove barriers
that prevent disabled persons from integrating fully into the designated environment.
Definitions

table_items.text: In this context accessible is defined as being:
Able to be easily obtained or used Easily understood or appreciated Able to be used by people who have a disability
In this context information is defined as:

That which informs i.e. facts provided or learned about something or someone What is conveyed or represented by a particular arrangement or sequence of things That from which data and knowledge can be derived i.e. data as processed, stored, or transmitted by a computer.
In this context standard is defined as:
A required or agreed level of quality or attainment Something used as a measure, norm, or model in comparative evaluations
Communication Professional must be qualified and registered to work as a communication professional within the field they are booked to work, such as BSL interpreter, Lipspeaker,
Communication Support is what the service user requires and is specific to their individuals communication needs.
is defined as the person who uses the services within the Trust, for example a patient. This also includes visitors, parents or carers of patients

Inclusive Groups
The following groups of patients / carers / service users are anticipated to be affected most directly by the Accessible Information Standard (2016) and are included in this policy:
People who are blind or have some visual loss
People who are deaf or Deaf or have some hearing loss
People who are deafblind
People who have a learning disability
The following groups are likely to also be affected by the Accessible Information Standard and are included in this policy.
People with aphasia
People with a mental health condition which affects their ability to communicate – i.e. dementia, severe depression
People with autism

It should be noted that these categories do not represent all of the groups who may be affected – the scope of the Standard includes all patients, service users, carers or parents with information or communication support needs relating to any kind of disability, impairment or sensory loss.
Exclusions

There are key aspects which are determined to be outside the purpose and scope of this policy but may well be covered in other areas of organisational policy and procedures. The exclusion criterion has been identified as follows:
The needs or preferences of staff or contractors of the organisation (except where they are also patients or carer/parent of the service users).
Where an individual has a communication preference which is not a “need” or “requirement” and which does not relate to a disability, impairment or sensory loss.

Where an individual has a difficulty with reading or understanding information, which is due to a reason other than a disability, impairment or sensory loss. (I.e. low literacy/learning difficulty as distinct from a learning “disability”).
Corporate communications produced/published by MSEFT which does not relate to direct patient care or services and does not directly affect individual's health or well-being.
Where other more widely used forms of disability support is required but does not relate to the provision of information or communication support.
Provision of information in foreign languages for reasons other than a disability i.e. interpretation and translation
Any matters relating to consent and capacity, including support for decision making, which is not related to information or communication support.
Communication support which is needed by or provided to a patient or service user as part of an agreed mental health care plan or other
mental health pathway of care (& MCA, 2005) – and which may be termed ‘therapeutic' in nature – is outside of the scope of the standards.
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive - The Trust has overall responsibility for ensuring that information and communication is accessible in line with the standards and legislation.
Associate Director of Nursing and Matrons

Heads of Nursing and Matrons are responsible for ensuring that staff are aware of and implement this policy and for bringing any issues which may affect implementation to the attention of the policy lead and the Director of Nursing.
Staff

Staff and others representing MSEFT are responsible across all Directorates for engaging in implementing the policy effectively and for bringing any issues which may affect implementation to their line Manager.

All staff and others representing MSEFT have a responsibility to ensure that they are communicating with patients, parents, carers and the public in a way which is effective and ensures that they have been understood. It is therefore the responsibility of all staff to ensure that they are aware of the relevant accessible information services available and how to access them.
Staff and others representing MSEFT will need to adhere to and complete a five staged approach:

Identification of needs - this means finding out if a patient, service user, carers and parents has any information or communication needs where they relate to a disability, impairment or sensory loss. The identification of needs should also be checked on every visit, For a degenerative condition such a macular degeneration or ushers syndrome, the needs are likely to change over time.
Recording the needs - in such a way that they are made highly visible. Accurately record within IT systems and the patient/service users notes the communication/information needs
Flagging the needs – using an alert/flag and paper based equivalent, to prompt staff to take all appropriate action

Sharing of needs - This means passing on information about a person's information/communication needs to people who are looking after them. It also means checking their needs are met every time they come to the service
Meeting the needs - This means taking action to ensure that the person's needs are met, for example sending them information in the right format or providing the communication support they need
Patient Electronic Systems - IT
Lorenzo and Medway are the systems that are identified as the Electronic Patient Record – (EPR) which conforms to the SCCI1605 Accessible Information Standards.
For a LORENZO USER GUIDE SEE APPENDIX 3
For a MEDWAY USER GUIDE SEE APPENDIX 4
Provision of Information and Communication Support Needs

Identification of needs - Communication and / or information needs must be identified at registration / upon first contact with the service or as soon as is practicable thereafter. The identification of needs should also be checked on every visit. For a degenerative condition such a macular degeneration or ushers syndrome, the needs are likely to change over time.

An initial standard question may be asked over the telephone, face-to-face at a reception desk, as part of a registration or admission forms or through an alternative process. The agreed standard question used will be “We are trying to improve the way we communicate with our patients, can you please tell us if you need information in a different format or communication support”.

A ‘standard line' as part of all correspondence to encourage people to contact the service if they have any information or communication needs, for example: “If you would like this letter or information in an alternative format, for example large print or easy read, or if you need help with communicating with us, please let us know”. Colour contrast should be added here e.g black on yellow background (to stop glare).

Recording the needs - Where individuals have information and / or communication needs relating to or caused by a disability, impairment or sensory loss, such information must be highly visible and recorded as part of the individual's first or next interaction with the service.

Clearly document communication or information needs to Lorenzo, the patient IT database to improve service for future access – refer back to section 8.2. Following the identification of the existence of a communication or information need, the specific nature of the support and / or format required must be identified using the four subsets.
Accessible information - Requires specific contact method;
Accessible information - Requires specific information format;
Accessible information - Requires communication professional;
Accessible information - Requires communication support.
Flagging the needs - A recording of an individual's information or communication support needs must be ‘highly visible' to relevant staff and professionals.

Once recorded and made highly visible, that an individual has information and / or communication support needs this requires a prompt for action to be taken by staff to meet those needs when the individual next interacts with the service / when the record is accessed for example generating correspondence in an alternative format i.e. email/large print/easy read.

Where a patient or service user has a carer/ family member, a discussion should take place to identify whether their carer has any information or communication needs. If they do, and with the consent of the patient or service user – and their carer – the information and / or communication support needs of the person's carer should be included as part of the patient / service user's record or notes, and flagged on the patient administration system appropriately for action.

Sharing of needs – staff and others representing MSEFT must ensure that information about individuals' information and / or communication support needs is included as part of existing data-sharing processes, and as a routine part of referral, transfers and discharge.
Staff and others representing MSEFT should be aware that the data-sharing is to support direct and indirect patient / service user care, and is not for reporting or analysis.

Staff and others representing MSEFT are informed that all information-sharing as part of this policy utilises existing data-sharing processes, including following existing information governance protocols and processes for the obtaining and recording of patient / service user consent.

Staff and others representing MSEFT are informed that information about individuals' information and / or communication needs should be included as part of referrals both within and between organisations, including (but not limited to) referrals from primary into secondary care, transfers and handovers between wards or departments, and discharge from an inpatient setting into the community.

Meeting the needs – it is a requirement that MSEFT must provide one or more communication or contact methods which are accessible to and useable by the patient, service user, carer or parent. The method(s) must enable the
individual to contact the service, and staff must use this method to contact the individual i.e.by email or text.

Staff and others representing MSEFT are informed that correspondence must not be sent to a patient or carer in a standard format where this is not suitable / not in line with their recorded needs, an example of accessible format is easy read/large font/audio – see section 10.4 below.
Procedures on Providing Communication and Information
Support
Here now follows an overview of the specifications as set out by NHS England which highlights the four subsets to be used. See Appendix 2

Accessible Information - requires specific contact method - This section relates to the need for services to provide accessible methods or mechanisms which individuals with information and / or communication needs are able to use to contact the service, and which the service uses to contact them.

Many patients / carers, including those who are D/Deaf or have some hearing loss, will not be able to use a telephone to, for example, book an appointment or receive test results. Alternative communication / contact methods which may be accessible to individuals with information and / or communication needs include:
Email;
Letter;
Text message;
Telephone;
Text relay.
video calls with an interpreter
Please consider that when writing to a person who has BSL
as their first language, it's important to write using plain English as BSL grammar is completely different to English. Accessible information - Requires specific information format
This section relates to a need to send correspondence or provide information to an individual in an alternative (non-standard print or non-print) format.
Staff and others representing MSEFT are informed that a standard print letter or any correspondence must not be sent to an individual who is unable to read or understand it.

Staff and others representing MSEFT to be aware that patient information such as that often contained with leaflets or booklets should be offered and made readily available in alternative, and commonly used accessible formats
where this is in support of direct patient / service user care (including self- care).
Alternative specific information methods which may be accessible to individuals with information and / or communication needs include:
Audio;
Audio MP3 by email, for internet download, on a CD;
Braille;
BSL DVD; internet download;
CD/DVD;
Easy Read;
Email; Word document attachment; PDF attachment;
Large print: point  Arial font; point 18 Arial font; point 20 Arial font;
Memory/USB/data stick;
Moon (alternative to Braille).
Captions to be used on all video platform such as CD/DVD's
Accessible information - Requires communication
professional

Where a need for support from a communication professional has been identified, then staff should arrange for this ensuring that interpreters and other communication professionals are suitably skilled, experienced, qualified and registered with a relevant professional body. These may include:
Advocate for people with a mental health need (IMHA);
Advocate for people with learning disabilities;
BSL Interpreter (& BSL hands on signing; BSL visual frame signing &/or BSL Sign Supported English SSE);
Deafblind block alphabet interpreter; Deafblind communicator-guide;
Deafblind haptic communication interpreter; Deafblind intervener;
Deafblind manual interpreter;
Learning Disability Nurse/communication support worker;
Lipspeaker
Lipspeakers with sign support
Note taker;
Speech-to-text reporter (STTR).

As the Accessible Information Standard aims to support individuals' rights to autonomy and, specifically, their ability to access health and social care services independently, and therefore the Trust will only use authorised and /or appropriately trained professionals, this is not to be generally provided by an individual's family members, friends or carers.

Staff and others representing MSEFT must be aware that in all instances, the individual patient, service user, carer or parent must be offered professional communication support where they have an identified need for communication using British Sign Language, deafblind manual or other alternative communication system.

Where an individual has sensory loss (hearing loss and / or visual loss) and no other impairment, a professional interpreter / communication professional must be used unless there is documented, supported evidence of the individual's explicit preference for the use of a family member / friend / carer.

The parameters in which the individual's family member / friend / carer is to be used must be agreed with the individual and recorded as part of their record or notes. This preference must also be regularly reviewed and must be reviewed whenever a new course of treatment / episode of care is started or proposed or significant decision or choice is to be made.

All efforts should be made by staff to accommodate requests for individual, consistent and / or male / female communication professionals where an individual is undergoing particularly invasive, intensive or sensitive procedures / courses of treatment, including care relating to pregnancy, maternity or sexual health, radio- and chemo-therapy, end of life care and when accessing mental health services.
Accessible information – remote access to communication
professional

In addition to the ‘traditional' approach of arranging for a particular communication professional to attend an appointment to support dialogue between an individual and a service provider, it is now possible to access such support remotely (or ‘virtually') over the internet available at MSEFT.

The technology can also be accessed via the individuals own Smartphone, tablet or computer, enabling quick and easy access to communication support. Staff and others representing MSEFT are advised to ask whether the individual has access to such technology as part of the information gathering process.
Staff and others representing MSEFT are informed of MSEFT website which now has the “BrowseAloud” facility this is assistive technology that adds the functionality of text-to-speech.
Accessible information - Requires communication support

This section relates to the provision of support to enable effective communication / conversation, for example by the provision or use of aids or equipment, or by health and/or social care staff making adjustments to their behaviour. This includes:
Longer appointment times;
Visual alert (reading their name on the screen);
Audible alert (being told or collected to go to an appointment room);
Communication supported by written notes;
Use of a hearing aid;
Non-verbal communication;
Electronic note-taking equipment;
Lip reading/Makaton;
Tadoma/speech reading/Voice Output Communication aid.
Hospital Passport
This is Me
Carers Passport

In urgent or emergency care settings, when it may not be possible to arrange for face-to-face or remote support from a communication professional in time, Staff and others representing MSEFT are to familiarise themselves with the communication aids and tools available on staff intranet such as the hospital communication book.

Staff and others representing MSEFT are also asked to familiarise themselves with and use the “Picture Menus” held within each Ward and Department for patients with communication and information support needs.
Easy read information is used to support people with a learning disability but can be useful for a range of people.

Requests from individuals with information and communication support needs made to be seen by one or more particular members of staff should be accommodated wherever possible. It is believed that familiarity with the nuances of a staff member, clinician or professional's dialect, accent and manner of speaking can assist in communicating effectively.

Staff and others representing MSEFT must accommodate the individual's need or requirement for a longer appointment to enable effective communication / the accessible provision of information. Any appointment requiring support from a communication professional will almost invariably take longer – because of the ‘three way' nature of the conversation – and allowance for this should be made. Please remember the importance of staff talking to the patient and not the communicator.
Staff and others representing MSEFT are informed that a minority of people with information and / or communication needs relating to a disability,

impairment or sensory loss have other multiple and / or complex needs, meaning that they require bespoke tools and / or communication support to enable or communication. Individuals with multiple and / or complex needs are more likely to use alternative and / or non-verbal communication methods, and may use a highly personal communication system, for example particular gestures or eye-pointing, which may require interpretation from someone close to them who understands them well.
Communication Tools

Staff and others representing MSEFT are advised to make use of the communication devices or tools usually used by the individual, and work with their carer(s), family members, support workers and others who know them well to identify and use communication approaches which maximise the involvement and inclusion of the individual. This includes:
A hospital Passport (for patients with learning disabilities
Talking Mats/Communication technology/Eye Gaze Systems
Disability Distress Assessment Tool (DisDat) (language of distress)
Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) aids
This is Me document (for patients with dementia)
IAM document (for patients with terminal illness)

Staff and others representing MSEFT are informed that the Audiology department can assist patients on the ward who have a hearing loss or additional communication needs, they have some equipment which can be borrowed for patient use and can be contacted on:

Hospital staff is advised to access or signpost to the Patient Information page on MSEFT intranet. When accessing the link use the icon to open the Accessible Information Standards which holds more accessible resources.
Training requirements
The Trust is committed to ensuring this policy and its sentiment is communicated to all staff, patients, and visitors and that the provision of accessible information is made accessible to all.

No formal training is needed regarding this policy, although ad-hoc training will be provided where requested. Staff information leaflets will be made available through Induction process. Staff information bulletins and Information flowcharts via Communications will ensure regular updates are available.
The policy will be made available on the Trust's internet and intranet and a copy will be sent to all senior managers, general managers and ward sisters for dissemination within their departments.
Continual communication throughout the Trust including external and internal websites together with social media will be used to promote this policy.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: The implementation of the accessible information standards in practice will be monitored by MSEFT Quality Governance Group on an ongoing basis via regular annual audit.
All MSEFT staff will be responsible for informing the line Manager and/or policy author of any issues affecting the compliance to this policy.
This policy will be subject to an annual review unless legislative changes determine otherwise.
The overall purpose of monitoring is to enable the Trust to assess how effectively this policy is being implemented.

Staff and others representing MSEFT will need to record a formal incident (Datix) each time an individual's information or communication support needs are not met. This will inform assessment of unmet need, support the making
of relevant adjustments / arrangements to meet needs, and highlight the importance of the Standard internally within MEHT and to commissioners.

Feedback will be captured from individuals with information and communication needs as part of their existing patient experience and patient engagement approaches (Friends & Family Test in alternative formats).

Whilst this policy is written for the main purpose of specifying recording practices and standards with regards to individuals' information and communication support needs (for use to support direct patient / service user care and access to services / support); As afore mentioned Staff should always cross reference this policy to other policies with specific reference to Safeguarding, MCA, data protection and sharing patient information to ensure compliance with the organisational policies and the law
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Safeguarding Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Trust of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary Equality Analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Appendix 1: Glossary of Terms

table_items.text: A person who supports someone who may otherwise find it difficult to communicate or to express their point of view.
Information which is able to be read or received and understood by the individual or group for which it is intended
Information provided in an alternative to standard printed or handwritten English, for example large print, braille or email.
BSL is a visual-gestural language that is the first or preferred language of many d/Deaf people and some deafblind people;
A person skilled in interpreting between BSL and English
Support which is needed to enable effective, accurate dialogue between a professional and a service user to take place.

A tool, device or document used to support effective communication with a disabled person. They may be generic or specific / bespoke to an individual. They often use symbols and / or pictures. They range from a simple paper chart to complex computer-aided or electronic devices.

A person who identifies as being deaf with a lowercase d is indicating that they have a significant hearing impairment. Many deaf people have lost their hearing later in life and as such may be able to speak and / or read English to the same extent as a hearing person. A person who identifies as being Deaf with an uppercase D is indicating that they are culturally Deaf and belong to the Deaf community.

Persons are regarded as Deafblind if their combined sight and hearing impairment causes difficulties with communication, access to information and mobility. This also includes people with a progressive sight and hearing loss

Persons with disabilities include those who have long-term physical, mental, intellectual or sensory impairments which in interaction with various barriers may hinder their full and effective participation in society on an equal basis with others.

Written information in an ‘easy read' format in which straightforward words and phrases are used supported by pictures, diagrams, symbols and / or photographs to aid understanding and to illustrate the text.
A functional limitation which may lead to a person being defined as disabled
A person able to transfer meaning from one spoken or signed language into another signed or spoken language
Printed information enlarged or otherwise reformatted to be provided in a larger font size which may be needed by a person who is blind or has some visual loss.
People with learning disabilities have life-long development needs and have difficulty with certain cognitive skills, although this varies greatly among different individuals.
A way of understanding or supporting understanding of speech by visually interpreting the lip and facial movements of the speaker.
A note taker produces a set of notes for people who are able to read English but need communication support, for example because they are d/Deaf.
A STTR types a verbatim (word for word) account of what is being said and the information appears on screen in real time for users to read.
(Systematised Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms) Classification of medical terms and phrases, providing codes, terms, synonyms and definitions
Text Relay enables people with hearing loss or speech impairment to access the telephone network. A relay assistant acts as an intermediary to convert speech to text and vice versa.
